facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 47 of 1972 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 47 of 1972.

facts.text: Appeal by certificate from Bombay High Court judgment and order dated August 14, 17, 1970 in Misc. Petition No. 324 of 1967.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by certificate from the judgment and order dated August 14, 17, 1970 of the Bombay High Court in Misc. Peti- tion No. 324 of 1967.

facts.text: Voltas Ltd. filed writ petition before Bombay High Court challenging appellate order dated May 2, 1967 by 1st appellant on excise duty liability for 1963.

anchor.surface_text: MATHEW, J.-Voltas Ltd., the respondent here, tiled a writ petition before the High Court of Bombay, challenging the validity of the appellate order passed by the 1st appellant on May 2, 1967, in respect of the liability of the respondent to pay excise duty for the year 1963

facts.text: Writ petition challenged orders of Assistant Collector of Central Excise on excise duty liability for 1962, 1964, 1965, 1966.

anchor.surface_text: and the orders of the Assist-ant Collector of Central Excise relating to the liability of the respondent to pay excise duty for the years 1962, 1964, 1965 and 1966,

facts.text: Demand notice for assessed amount of Rs. 27,57,177.19 challenged in writ petition.

anchor.surface_text: as also the numberice demanding the assessed amount of Rs. 27,57,177.19.

facts.text: Bombay High Court allowed the writ petition.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court allowed the petition. This appeal, by certificate, is against that order.

facts.text: Voltas Ltd. is a company registered under the Companies Act.

anchor.surface_text: Voltas Ltd. is a companypany registered under the Companies Act.

facts.text: Voltas manufactures air conditioners, water coolers and component parts thereof.

anchor.surface_text: It carries on, among others, the business of manufacturing air companyditioners, water companylers and companyponent parts thereof.

facts.text: Voltas organises sales from head office at Bombay and branch offices at Calcutta, Delhi, Madras, Bangalore, Cochin and Lucknow.

anchor.surface_text: It organises the sales of these articles from its head office at Bombay as also from its branch offices at Calcutta, Delhi, Madras, Bangalore, Cochin and Lucknow.

facts.text: Direct sales to consumers at list prices from offices constitute 90 to 95 per cent of production during relevant period.

anchor.surface_text: From these offices it effects direct sales to companysumers at list prices and the sales so effected companye to about 90 to 95 per cent of its production of these articles in the factory in question during the relevant period.

facts.text: Voltas sells articles to wholesale dealers pursuant to agreements with terms similar to Exhibit A.

anchor.surface_text: Apart from these sales, it also sells the articles to wholesale dealers from different parts of the companyntry in pursuance of agreements entered into with them. The agreements with the wholesale dealers for the relevant years companytained terms and companyditions similar to those mentioned in Exhibit A annexed to the writ petition.

facts.text: Agreements provide dealers sell at list prices fixed by Voltas, Voltas sells at list less 22 per cent discount.

anchor.surface_text: The agreements provided, among other things, that the dealers should number sell the articles sold to them except in accordance with the list prices fixed by the respondent, that the respondent would sell them the articles at the list prices less 22 per cent discount,

facts.text: Agreements provide dealers not entitled to discount on accessories and must give service to units sold in territory.

anchor.surface_text: that the dealers will number be entitled to any discount on the prices of accessories mentioned in, the price schedule and that the dealers should give service to the units sold in their territory.

facts.text: Excise duty imposed on air conditioners, water coolers and parts from March 1, 1961 on ad valorem value.

anchor.surface_text: Excise duty on the basis of ad valorem value was imposed on air companyditioners, water companylers and parts of water companylers from March 1, 1961.

facts.text: Voltas case: list price after deducting 22 per cent discount constitutes wholesale cash price.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents case was that the list price after 1092 deducting the discount of 22 per cent allowed to the wholesale dealers would companystitute the wholesale cash price, for ascertaining the real value of the articles.

facts.text: Excise authorities accepted Voltas case and assessed up to end of 1962 on list price minus 22 per cent.

anchor.surface_text: This case was accepted by the excise authorities and assessments were made upto the end of 1962 on that basis.

facts.text: In April 1964, Superintendent of Central Excise intimated assessment on retail price basis, not wholesale cash price.

anchor.surface_text: In April, 1964, the Superintendent of Central Excise intimated the respondent that excise duty would be assessed and levied number on the footing of the wholesale cash price but on the basis of the retail price

facts.text: Superintendent passed three orders dated September 5, 1964 and one dated September 10, 1964 assessing duty for 1963 on list prices.

anchor.surface_text: and, by his three orders dated September 5, 1964 and one dated September 10, 1964, he assessed the respondent to excise duty in respect of the sales on the footing of list prices for sale to companysumers for the period from January 1, 1963, to December 31, 1963,

facts.text: Demand notice dated October 8, 1964 served for Rs. 27,57,177.19.

anchor.surface_text: and a numberice of demand dated October 8, 1964, was served on the respondent calling upon it to pay the above sum.

facts.text: Voltas appeal against orders dismissed by 1st appellant on May 2, 1967.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent filed an appeal against the orders but that was dismissed by the 1st appellant by his order dated May 2, 1967

facts.text: Bombay High Court held price to wholesale dealers less discount is wholesale cash price under s.4(a).

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that the price for which the articles were sold to the wholesale dealers less the discount allowed to them under the agreements represented the wholesale cash price and that exise duty was chargeable under s. 4 a  of the Act.

facts.text: Appellants contended agreements confer extra-commercial advantages, sales not to independent purchasers.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants companytended that the agreements with the whole- sale dealers companyferred certain extra-commercial advantages upon them, and so, the sales to them were number sales to independent purchasers but to favoured ones,

facts.text: Supreme Court held sales to wholesale dealers constitute wholesale cash price under s.4(a) even with agreements.

anchor.surface_text: We do number think that for a wholesale market to exist, it is necessary that there should be a market in the physical sense of the term where articles of a like kind or quality are or companyld be sold or that the articles should be sold to so-called independent buyers.

facts.text: 22 per cent discount treated as trade discount, no contention otherwise before High Court.

anchor.surface_text: There was numbercontention by the appellants before the High Court that the discount allowed to the  1  1963 Supp. 1 S.C.R. 586, 1099 wholesale dealers was number trade discount.
tiled a writ petition before the High Court of Bombay, challenging the validity of the appellate order passed by the 1st appellant on May 2, 1967,

The High Court held that the price for which the articles were sold to the wholesale dealers less the discount allowed to them under the agreements represented the wholesale cash price and that exise duty was chargeable under s. 4 a  of the Act. Section 4 of the Act provides Where under this Act, any article is chargeable with duty at a rate dependent on the value of the article, such value shall be- deemed to be-  a  the wholesale cash price for which an article of the like kind and quality is sold or is capable of being sold at the time of the removal of the article chargeable with duty from the factory or any other premises of manufacture or production for delivery at the place of manufacture or production, or if a wholesale market does number exist for such article at such place, at the nearest place where such market exists, or 1093  b  where such price is number ascertainable, the price at which an article of the like kind and quality is sold or is capable of being sold by the manufacturer or producer, or his agent , at the time of the removal of the article chargeable with duty from such factory or other premises for delivery at the place of manufacture or production, or if such article is number sold or is number. capable of being sold at such place, at any other place nearest these to Explanation In determining the price of any article under this section, numberabatement or deduction shall be allowed except in respect of trade discount and the amount of duty payable at the time of the removal of the article chargeable with duty from the factory or other premises aforesaid.

concepts.interpretation: The price at which articles are sold to wholesale dealers less trade discount constitutes the wholesale cash price under clause (a) if sales are at arms length, even with agreements imposing service obligations; clause (b) applies only if (a) price not ascertainable.

anchor.surface_text: Voltas Ltd. is a companypany registered under the Companies Act.

issues.text: whether the respondent was liable to be charged with excise duty on the basis of the price of retail sales made by it directly to the consumers from its head office and branch offices under clause (b) of s. 4 or whether it was liable to be charged on the basis of the price payable by the wholesale dealers, after deducting the 22 per cent discounts under clause (a) of s. 4 of the Central Excises and Salt Act, 1944

anchor.surface_text: The question that was canvassed before the High Court was whether the respondent was liable to be chargedwith excise duty on the basis of the price of retail sales made byit directly to the companysumers from its head office and branch officesunder clause  b  of s. 4 or whether it was liable to be charged onthe basis of the price payable by the wholesale dealers, after deducting the 22 per cent discounts under clause  a  of s. 4 of the, Central Excises and Salt Act 1944  hereinaf

issues.text: whether the agreements with the wholesale dealers conferred certain extra-commercial advantages upon them, and so, the sales to them were not sales to independent purchasers but to favoured ones, and, therefore, the price charged would not represent the wholesale cash price as mentioned in s. 4(a) of the Act

anchor.surface_text: The appellants contended that the agreements with the whole- sale dealers conferred certain extra-commercial advantages upon them, and so, the sales to them were number sales to independent purchasers but to favoured ones, and, therefore, the price charged would number represent the wholesale cash price as mentioned in s. 4 a  of the Act. They argued that s. 4 a  visualizes a wholesale market at the place of manufacture where articles of like kind and quality are sold or companyld be sold and that it also postulates a market where any wholesale purchaser can purchase the articles, and, as numberarticles of a like kind and quality were sold, at or near the place of manufacture,

issues.text: whether for a wholesale market to exist, it is necessary that there should be a market in the physical sense of the term where articles of a like kind or quality are or could be sold or that the articles should be sold to so-called independent buyers

anchor.surface_text: We do number think that for a wholesale market to exist, it is necessary that there should be a market in the physical sense of the term where articles of a like kind or quality are or companyld be sold or that the articles should be sold to so-called independent buyers. Even if it is assumed that the latter part of s. 4  a  proceeds on the assumption that the former part will apply only if there is a wholesale market at the place of manufacture for articles of a like kind and quality, the question is what exactly is the companycept of wholesale market in the companytext.

issues.text: whether articles of a like kind and quality is a phrase which suggests goods other than those under assessment and that one must disregard the price fetched by the sale of the goods themselves

anchor.surface_text: It was further argued that articles of a like kind and quality is a phrase which suggests goods other than those under assessment and that one must disregard the price fetched by the sale of the goods themselves. We do number think that [...] the application of clause  a  of s.4 of the Act does number depend upon any hypothesis to the effect that at the time and place of sale, any further articles of like kind and quality should have been sold.

issues.text: what exactly is the meaning of the term the wholesale cash price

anchor.surface_text: The next question is what exactly is the meaning of the term the wholesale cash price ? In Vacuum Oil Company v. Secretary of State for India in Council 1 , it was held that the term means the price paid by retail traders on wholesale purchase. The essence of the idea is that the purchase must be a wholesale purchase and number a retail one.

issues.text: whether 22 per cent discount allowed under the agreements with the wholesale dealers was trade discount

anchor.surface_text: The appellant contended that 22 per cent discount allowed under the agreements with the wholesale dealers was number trade discount. On the round that there was numberevidence to show that the discount allowed was trade discount within the meaning of the Explanation to S. 4.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants contended that the agreements with the whole- sale dealers conferred certain extra-commercial advantages upon them, and so, the sales to them were not sales to independent purchasers but to favoured ones, and, therefore, the price charged would not represent the wholesale cash price as mentioned in s. 4 a  of the Act.

arguments.claim: s.4(a) visualizes a wholesale market at place of manufacture where like kind/quality sold/capable of being sold, and any wholesale purchaser can buy; no such market as sales confined to favoured buyers

anchor.surface_text: They argued that s. 4 a  visualizes a wholesale market at the place of manufacture where articles of like kind and quality are sold or could be sold and that it also postulates a market where any wholesale purchaser can purchase the articles, and, as no articles of a like kind and quality were sold, at or near the place of manufacture,

arguments.court_reasoning: Supreme Court agrees; sales qualify under s.4(a)

arguments.claim: No need for physical wholesale market or sales to independent buyers; potentiality of wholesale sales suffices; agreements with commercial advantages ok if arms-length

anchor.surface_text: We do not think that for a wholesale market to exist, it is necessary that there should be a market in the physical sense of the term where articles of a like kind or quality are or could be sold or that the articles should be sold to so-called independent buyers.

arguments.claim: Sales to wholesale dealers under arms-length agreements are wholesale sales even with stipulated commercial advantages like service obligations

anchor.surface_text: Even if it is assumed that the latter part of s. 4 a  proceeds on the assumption that the former part will apply only if there is a wholesale market at the place of manufacture... the sale to the wholesale dealers did not cease to be wholesale sales merely because...

arguments.claim: Goods under assessment can be 'like kind and quality'; no need for other sales at time/place

anchor.surface_text: It was further argued that articles of a like kind and quality is a phrase which suggests goods other than those under assessment... We do not think that ... the application of clause a  of s.4 of the Act does not depend upon any hypothesis to the effect that at the time and place of sale, any further articles of like kind and quality should have been sold.

arguments.claim: Ford Motor Co. case: sales to authorised distributors less discount is wholesale cash price under similar s.30(a) Sea Customs Act despite agreements/monopoly

anchor.surface_text: In Ford Motor Company-of India Limited v. Secretary of State... the Privy Council held that the price charged by the appellants to the distributors excluding the assembling allowance was the wholesale cash price...

arguments.claim: High Court decisions like National Tobacco, Vengunta etc. incorrect on requiring independent/favoured buyer distinction for arms-length dealer agreements

anchor.surface_text: We do not think that these decisions in so far as they hold that the price of sales to wholesale dealers would not represent the wholesale cash price... merely because the manufacturer has entered into agreements... are correct.

arguments.court_reasoning: Agreements at arms-length in ordinary course qualify

arguments.claim: Wholesale cash price ascertained only from arms-length transactions; favoured buyer due to extra-commercial considerations (e.g. relative) excluded

anchor.surface_text: There can be no doubt that the wholesale cash price has to be ascertained only on the basis of transactions at arms length. If there is a special or favoured buyer... because of extra-commercial considerations... the price charged... would not be the wholesale cash price

arguments.claim: Quantum of wholesale sales irrelevant; even few/scanty sales qualify if arms-length

anchor.surface_text: Once wholesale dealings at arms length are established... may not depend upon the number of such wholesale dealing. The fact that the respondent sold 90 to 95 per cent... would not make the price of the wholesale sales... any the less the wholesale cash price

arguments.claim: Wholesale cash price means price paid by retail traders on wholesale purchase; essence is wholesale not retail

anchor.surface_text: The next question is what exactly is the meaning of the term the wholesale cash price ? In Vacuum Oil Company... it was held that the term means the price paid by retail traders on wholesale purchase. The essence of the idea is that the purchase must be a wholesale purchase and not a retail one.

arguments.claim: Excise is tax on manufacture/production; s.4 value excludes post-manufacturing costs/profits (selling cost/profit, transport)

anchor.surface_text: Excise is a tax on the production and manufacture of goods see Union of India v. Delhi Cloth and General Mills. Section 4... provides that the real value should be found after deducting the selling cost and selling profit...

arguments.claim: 22% discount is trade discount allowable under Explanation to s.4

anchor.surface_text: There was no contention by the appellants before the High Court that the discount allowed to the wholesale dealers was not trade discount... A trade discount is a percentage deduction from the regular list or catalogue price of goods.

holdings.text: The price for which the articles were sold to the wholesale dealers less the discount allowed to them under the agreements represented the wholesale cash price under s.4(a) of the Act and excise duty was chargeable on that basis.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that the price for which the articles were sold to the wholesale dealers less the discount allowed to them under the agreements represented the wholesale cash price and that exise duty was chargeable under s. 4 a  of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Supreme Court upholds High Court by rejecting appellants' contentions on extra-commercial advantages, physical market requirement, and favoured buyers; sales to dealers under arms-length agreements qualify as wholesale market under s.4(a).

holdings.text: For a wholesale market to exist under s.4(a), it is not necessary that there should be a market in the physical sense or that articles should be sold to so-called independent buyers; potentiality of wholesale sales suffices.

anchor.surface_text: We do not think that for a wholesale market to exist, it is necessary that there should be a market in the physical sense of the term where articles of a like kind or quality are or could be sold or that the articles should be sold to so-called independent buyers.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects appellants' textual argument requiring physical market and open sales; wholesale market means potentiality even under agreements conferring commercial advantages.

holdings.text: Sales to wholesale dealers under agreements conferring commercial advantages (like service obligations) do not cease to be wholesale sales if made at arms length in ordinary course of business.

anchor.surface_text: Even if it is assumed that the latter part of s. 4 a proceeds on the assumption that the former part will apply only if there is a wholesale market at the place of manufacture... the sale to the wholesale,- dealers did not cease to be wholesale sales merely because...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes extra-commercial favoured sales (e.g. relatives) from arms-length commercial agreements; analogies to Ford Motor Co. precedent.

holdings.text: The application of clause (a) of s.4 does not depend on any hypothesis that further articles of like kind and quality should have been sold at the time and place; goods under assessment themselves qualify as like kind and quality.

anchor.surface_text: We also think that the application of clause a of s.4 of the Act does not depend upon any hypothesis to the effect that at the time and place of sale, any further articles of like kind and quality should have been sold.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects appellants' interpretation requiring other goods; price of goods themselves can represent wholesale cash price.

holdings.text: Wholesale cash price under s.4(a) must be ascertained only from arms-length transactions; excludes prices to special or favoured buyers due to extra-commercial considerations.

anchor.surface_text: There can be no doubt that the wholesale cash price has to be ascertained only on the basis of transactions at arms length. If there is a special or favoured buyer... because of extra-commercial considerations... the price charged... would not be the wholesale cash price

holdings.reasoning_summary: Clarifies standard for valid wholesale price; sole distributor ok if terms fair and commercial.

holdings.text: Determination of wholesale cash price under s.4(a) does not depend on the quantum or number of wholesale dealings if arms-length established.

anchor.surface_text: Once wholesale dealings at arms length are established... may not depend upon the number of such wholesale dealing. The fact that the respondent sold 90 to 95 per cent... would not make the price of the wholesale sales... any the less the wholesale cash price

holdings.reasoning_summary: Irrelevant that 90-95% sales direct to consumers; few wholesale sales suffice if qualifying.

holdings.text: The term 'wholesale cash price' means the price paid by retail traders on wholesale purchase; essence is wholesale purchase not retail.

anchor.surface_text: The next question is what exactly is the meaning of the term the wholesale cash price ? In Vacuum Oil Company v. Secretary of State for India in Council 1 , it was held that the term means the price paid by retail traders on wholesale purchase.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows Vacuum Oil precedent defining term in contra-distinction to retail price.

holdings.text: The 22 per cent discount allowed to wholesale dealers is trade discount within the meaning of the Explanation to s.4.

anchor.surface_text: There was no contention by the appellants before the High Court that the discount allowed to the wholesale dealers was not trade discount... A trade discount is a percentage deduction from the regular list or catalogue price of goods.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No prior contention; defined as percentage from list price; no evidence otherwise.

holdings.text: High Court decisions (National Tobacco, Vengunta, etc.) holding that sales to dealers under agreements with commercial advantages do not represent wholesale cash price under s.4(a) are incorrect.

anchor.surface_text: We do not think that these decisions in so far as they hold that the price of sales to wholesale dealers would not represent the wholesale cash price... merely because the manufacturer has entered into agreements... are correct.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Overrules insofar as requiring independent purchasers without arms-length consideration; Ford Motor controls.

precedents.citation: Ford Motor Company-of India Limited v. Secretary of State for India in Council 1

anchor.surface_text: In Ford Motor Company-of India Limited v. Secretary of State for India in Council 1  the appellants before the Privy Council, who imported Ford Motor vehicles from Canada to India.

precedents.case_name: Ford Motor Company of India Limited v Secretary of State for India in Council
precedents.cited_proposition: price charged by importers to authorised distributors less discount is wholesale cash price under s.30(a) Sea Customs Act despite agreements and monopoly supply
precedents.cited_holding: the price charged by the appellants to the distributors excluding the assembling allowance was the wholesale cash price, less trade discount

precedents.citation: National Tobacco, Co. of India Ltd. v. Collector of Central, Excise and others 1

anchor.surface_text: In National Tobacco, Co. of India Ltd. v. Collector of Central, Excise and others 1  a learned single Judge of that Court held that the word wholesale market must mean a place where articles are habitually sold to any person who wishes to make a purchase

precedents.case_name: National Tobacco Co of India Ltd v Collector of Central Excise
precedents.cited_proposition: wholesale market requires sales to any person wishing to purchase; sales to stockists/dealers do not constitute wholesale market unless independent
precedents.cited_holding: the word wholesale market must mean a place where articles are habitually sold to any person who wishes to make a purchase

precedents.citation: Union of India v. Vengunta Suryaprakasa Rao and Another 2

anchor.surface_text: In the Union of India v. Vengunta Suryaprakasa Rao and Another 2 , the Court said that the sale to wholesale distributors with whom the company in question had entered into agreements

precedents.case_name: Union of India v Vengunta Suryaprakasa Rao
precedents.cited_proposition: sales to wholesale distributors under agreements conferring commercial advantages do not constitute wholesale cash price under s.4(a)
precedents.cited_holding: sale to wholesale distributors with whom the company had entered into agreements for sale stipulating commercial advantages would not constitute wholesale cash price

precedents.citation: Amco Batteries  P  Ltd. Bangalore v. Assistant Collector, Central Excise, Bangalore and Another 1

anchor.surface_text: In Amco Batteries  P  Ltd. Bangalore v. Assistant Collector, Central Excise, Bangalore and Another 1 , the Court said that wholesale price means the price which a wholesale dealer

precedents.case_name: Amco Batteries P Ltd v Assistant Collector Central Excise
precedents.cited_proposition: wholesale market is where goods are sold or capable of being sold to independent buyers without restriction
precedents.cited_holding: wholesale market is a place where goods in question or goods of like kind and quality are sold or capable of being sold to independent buyers

precedents.citation: Collector of Central Excise and Others v. Shankarlal Agarwalla  2

anchor.surface_text: In Collector of Central Excise and Others v. Shankarlal Agarwalla  2  the Court followed its earlier decision already referred to. and said that the wholesale cash price means the price

precedents.case_name: Collector of Central Excise v Shankarlal Agarwalla
precedents.cited_proposition: wholesale market requires habitual sales to anybody wishing to purchase at wholesale price; sales to stockists do not convert factory place into wholesale market
precedents.cited_holding: wholesale cash price means the price which a wholesale dealer charges for his goods when he sells them in wholesale units in a wholesale market

precedents.citation: Frizair Corporation v. The Collector of Central Excise 3

anchor.surface_text: In Frizair Corporation v. The Collector of Central Excise 3 , the Court held that a sale to a favoured buyer cannot be regarded as a sale in a wholesale market

precedents.case_name: Frizair Corporation v Collector of Central Excise
precedents.cited_proposition: sale to favoured buyer or at factory by itself does not constitute wholesale cash price under s.4(a)
precedents.cited_holding: a sale to a favoured buyer cannot be regarded as a sale in a wholesale market

precedents.citation: Vacuum Oil Company v. Secretary of State for India in Council 1

anchor.surface_text: In Vacuum Oil Company v. Secretary of State for India in Council 1 , it was held that the term means the price paid by retail traders on wholesale purchase.

precedents.case_name: Vacuum Oil Company v Secretary of State for India in Council
precedents.cited_proposition: wholesale cash price means price paid by retail traders on wholesale purchase, in contradistinction to retail price
precedents.cited_holding: the term means the price paid by retail traders on wholesale purchase. The essence of the idea is that the purchase must be a wholesale purchase

precedents.citation: Union of India v. Delhi Cloth and General Mills 1

anchor.surface_text: Excise is a tax on the production and manufacture of goods see Union of India v. Delhi Cloth and General Mills 1 . Section 4 of the Act therefore provides that the real value

precedents.case_name: Union of India v Delhi Cloth and General Mills
precedents.cited_proposition: excise is a tax on the production and manufacture of goods
